intro: Pulsatilla teklae, commonly known as the Tekla's pasqueflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, which includes many showy flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and large, showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale yellow. It thrives in alpine and subalpine environments, often growing in rocky or well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
